You have come to the end of this tutorial.üèÅ You can exit with the help of the back button at the top left or return to the previous steps with the arrow keys.
The clue marked in green with a 3 in it has a diamond in one of its neighbors. The remaining 2 neighbors should also receive diamonds.
The clue marked in green with a 1 in it has only one neighbor left. This neighbor should also receive a diamond.
The 2 diamonds in these 4 boxes also affect the clue marked in green. Therefore, a cross should be placed to the remaining neighbor of the clue with 2 in it.
So there are 2 diamonds in total in these 4 boxes.
The clue marked in green and containing 1 must also have a diamond in one of its 2 neighbors.
One of the neighbors of the clue marked in green has a diamond. So one of the remaining 2 neighbors has to have a diamond.
The clue with 1 in it on the right has only one empty neighbor left. A diamond is put to the last empty neighbor by switching to the diamond from the switch box.
Since there will definitely be 2 diamonds in these 3 gray-coloured neighbors, the other neighbors cannot have diamonds. Crosses should be placed in these neighbors.
As you can see, these 3 boxes are also neighbors of the clue with 2 in it. So the 2 diamonds in these 3 boxes affect it as well.
For example these 2 clues have 3 neighbors and 2 of these 3 boxes must be diamonds.
What needs to be looked at in these cases is the common effects of diamonds placed on the neighbors of the clues on the other clues.
Clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them may not be found in every question or may be insufficient to reach a solution.
So the clue with 2 in it has got all the diamonds it should have and its other neighbors cannot have diamonds. Crosses are placed on these neighbors by switching to the cross by pressing switch box.
As you can notice, 2 of the 4 diamonds we have placed are the neighbors of the clue with the number 2 in it.
As seen in the example, clues with 4 written in it have only 4 neighbors. These neighbors can definitely be filled with diamonds
The first thing to look for when solving is the clues that have as many neighbors as the number written in them.
"In Mine Sweeper, number clues show how many of their neighbours have diamonds. "
Welcome to Mine Sweeper Tutorial. You can take part in the solbving process by tapping the blinking boxes throughout the tutorial.
